IntroductionFranchise Hockey Manager 3 is developed and published by Out of the Park Developments. They seem to specialize on making sports management simulators such as the much better, Out of the Park Baseball 17. And I would have to be Out of My Mind to spend nearly 40 dollars on the “masterpiece” I’m about to present to you. GameplayI haven't had this much fun since decorating my house. In fact, watching paint dry would probably make for a better review subject. Before you dismiss my unabashed opinion of this title as simply another review writing geek hating on sports games, I’ll have you know that my love affair with the ice rink goes back quite a few years. Now, that does not mean I was ever a professional ice skater or hockey player, but I wasn’t clueless about it either. To my major disappointment, Franchise Hockey Manager 3 is far worse than any cheap football manager I’ve ever played. Those had far better simulations of the games themselves. More on that, in a bit. You might think I’m comparing apples to oranges, but sports management video games are fairly similar in the User Interface department at least, if not game mechanics. Speaking of the UI, it’s as dreary as it can ever get. Micromanagement is a necessity even if you delegate an AI coach to deal with the players and their much needed training and tactics during the matches. In the end, it’s gonna come back biting you somewhere once you see just how bad your team fares and you will have to become the coach as well if you wish to stand any chance of finishing the championship in a dignified position. Even if you have so many leagues to choose from North America, Europe and even a few Asian nations, it all plays the same and you don’t even have a randomized minimal visual style to differentiate one team from another (apart from a small logo). As for the hockey players, you don’t see any pictures or portraits with them at all. In FHM 3, only John Does seem to play no matter if you’re in a small town in Canada or in Japan The simulation of the hockey games made me think I’m play testing a game from the early ‘90s. You have the crude drawing of the Ice hockey rink over which a puck moves back and forth with some text below it with the commentator’s insights. It gets old really fast.The title’s spartan approach in regards to its aestethics is sadly worsened by the lack of any sounds. I really wouldn’t have believed it if I didn’t actually try to play and “enjoy” this game. Even shovelware on Steam, costing 10 cents has more sounds than FHM 3. It’s beyond me, the dev team’s decision to esckew even a barebones repetitive tune or a crowd cheering. Anything is better than silence. Did I mention this game loads very slowly? Its sluggishness is inexplicable considering most modern CPUs. You’re telling me I can host lighitning fast 3D battles with thousands of soldiers in a Total War game, but a 2D hockey manager requires 10 minutes just to load all its database if you start a new game? Don’t even get me started on the game’s settings and resolution issues. FHM 3’s idea of fullscreen still implies that I hide the taskbar. Steam Overlay doesn’t even wish to start along with the game, not that I was just dying to showcase any screenshots with it. Pros+ Simulates the stress of being a sports manager/coach, I guess?+ Steam Achievements & Steam Trading Cards.Cons- UI and basic Steam overlay issues- Immensely overpriced- Lacks almost any form of imagery- No soundsResult / Final thoughtsI don’t think I’ll need to play this genre for quite some time from now. I’ve had my fill and no matter how much of a fan I might be of simulations in general terms, sometimes arcades have their merits. Not having even a small measure of visual aid, harms such management games a lot. I knew they are a niche genre and I respect their well-accustomed playerbase, but there are enough alternatives to Franchise Hockey Manager 3. Even it’s predecessor, which is at the time of this writing 17 dollars cheaper, seems like a smarter choice. Asking $36.99 is just outrageous.Rating 40/100 This review was submitted for Imperial Reviews, through the generous contribution of RedHill.

												Overall, this is a good game. First off, it is the best hockey sim on the market, even though that market is small. The gameplay is very fun. When it comes to things such as stats and player progression, it is usually very accurate. The NHL License is also a very nice touch and helps make the game feel more complete. The "main" Path to Glory mode is a nice addition. While improving the simulation engine from FHM2, they gave a more realistic feeling to the game. Essentially it is like role playing a GM, where you get points to use that will affect how you do things such as train players, or make deals. It is an interesting spin on the normal game, that also shouldn't deter people. If you want more freedom, then sandbox mode is for you. If you want a more realistic feeling, then PTG is the better option. Both game modes are fun. One little thing i did enjoy was the slight upgrade to the UI. Not as nice as OOTP yet, but i do like the upgrade from FHM2There are a few downsides to FHM3 however. One is that there are no online leagues. I personally never played them so idc, but if you are a person who strictly plays them, then sadly this game isn't for you. The developers said that they didnt feel right giving us an incomplete and bad online mode, and would rather work on it until it is up to their standards which i completly agree with and understand. The second thing that this game is missing is the vastness of customization options. I'm use to played OOTP17 which has many, however that series has been around much longer so it makes sense. I still love being able to create my own league, but the little things like fully personalizing league and conference set ups or determining draft order would be nice additions. The only other thing i have noticed is that the game can have slow loading times at points, but nothing game-breaking so far. I already see a good change frmo playing the beta the past few weeks however. This series is only in its third edition, but has made very good improvements each time. The developers have shown this game has promise. The overall game play is good. With these types of games, getting the simulation engine to run smoothly is the most important thing, and FHM3 does a pretty good job at that. Even though it is lacking in customization options for people who enjoy more of a sandbox experience, and online leagues, that game is still enjoyable.8/10

												As a giant hockey fan, as well as an OOTP addict I was very excited to give this game a try. However, I have found there is still a lot of work needed for this game to be considered a realistic sim. Perhaps this game satisifes the average hockey fan, but for me there is a lot to be fixed.First and foremost are player ratings and positions. Too many players have terrible ratings (either rated much too low or much too high) and their positions are all wrong. I put hours into re-rating players and it still is hard to make accurate because of the numerous attribute listings and the uncertainty of their impact on overall rating and potential. Also in terms of positions, many forwards have center listed as their position when they haven't played one game in the NHL at that spot. Also, I'm assuming that LD and RD listed as seperate positions are in someway neccessary for the AI to set line ups because otherwise that totally complicates things and is sort of ridiculous. Off the top of my head, contracts aren't right. We often see a player being paid different amounts in certain years of their contract, but they still have a set AAV which becomes their cap hit. FHM missed the mark on this because then we have certain players (i.e Marian Hossa) already part way through their contract. Therefore, this game has not taken in to account their previous years and the cap hit becomes wrong for said players.Trading needs to be improved as well. Perhaps I would find it more acceptable with accurate player ratings but the AI is way out to lunch a lot of times.Finally, the player roles is a mess. Much too complicated and with too many roles to chose from (specifically you have basically the same role just described in 5 different ways). You also end up struggling to get good chemistry on lines and the only way to find it is by having a skater playing a role that is not realistic to their real life ability and style.In the end, a solid game for a new or average hockey fan. For myself, I want much more of a realistic game that I have become accustomed to by playing OOTP. I have high hopes for FHM4, but cannot reccomend FHM3 at this time.

Pre-Release, Public Beta ReviewFranchise Hockey Manager 3 is quite an improvement from the previous installment, where glitches and a poor interface ruined gameplay. FHM2 felt uncompleted, and just far too difficult to get into. The best point to be made about FHM3 for myself is the new tactical system. Just the sheer amount of roles and worldwide strategies puts the game above last year's edition. Looking at the other new features - NHL License, Path to Glory, Sandbox, International, Rebuilt Injury System, Updated Development Process, Updated Interface, Steamworks Support, and Steam Achievements - while all are nice additions, the one that stands out is Path to Glory. While the gamemode actually runs extremely slow in simulation, the concept and basics are there. Obviously needs a lot of tweaking, for example, the in-game sim at times freezes, and the boxscore doesn't always show the second goaltender if you take out your starter mid-game. But of course, it hasn't been publicly released yet, so I'll let it slide. The international aspects, while interesting, also has many issues, such as two-goal overtimes. Overall, the AI has gotten better, but still could use improvement, and there are definitely too many injuries. Apart from that, the game seems solid, although I do wish the simulation would be as quick OOTP, and if not, at least that we could see stats durinng the loading times.

Though improvements could still be made in my opinion(certain font sizes, bolding, etc), the GUI is now wonderfully shaded with your team's colours - this has had a huge impact on my interest to learn the game more.This iteration of FHM features more in-depth ratings and player stats, more logically and cleanly placed information and controls that are relative to what your task is and a great tactics system, which I'm learning to love.  I may be wrong about this, but it seems the game/match engine is improved quite a bit as well.Having been disgusted in recent years with EA's NHL game(which I did not buy after trying, and will not play), this is about as good of a replacement as there is.  Obviously, you don't play the games, but there is a plethora of depth in this title that EA's title came nowhere close to, so anyone who enjoys the managerial side of hockey can appreciate this game.I'm still hoping for a visual match engine; something like what Football Manager has, but better of course.  I know it's probably a long way off, but I think this game is headed there.The inclusion of the workshop is huge plus!  Whether you want to create the Charlestown Chiefs, or replicate your beer league hockey team, you can do it.There is always room for improvement, but I feel that FHM has transformed from a game I have hope for, to a game I actually want to play.  It needs to be noted that I have not experienced any of the crashes that some of the other reviewers have, not yet any way.

												  If you like playing GM Mode in the EA Sports NHL series, then this is the game for you. Now it has some small negatives, but if you do not mind a few hiccups then keep on reading.     What makes me happy about this game is the depth in the expansive hockey world this game features. There are many features i wish NHL games had in their GM Mode, and this game delivers in that area of depth. Simple things like renegotiating contracts mid season, and no trade/no move clauses are a very nice thing to have. I love the scouting in this game, and you are able to see what a player has for season stats to give you a general idea of what they may be capable of, which of course the NHL series does not have. Being able to command a national team for me puts the cherry on top. Back to negotiating contracts, it is nice to not only be able to select the length of contract, but fluctuate how much money the player will make each year, so front loaded contracts are a thing! If you are really into statistics, this game has got your back. The game has many advanced stats such as Corsi. As well they are active on the forums and are constantly working on updating the game. There are so many more things, but it would take too long to write it all out.      Now, for the negatives. The games can have a tendency to crash, but if you have the game on auto save weekly, you won't lose too much work. People have complained about the UI, but I disagree and I believe its one of the better ones out there, easy to navigate. Now, I had a game breaking crash in year 4, and no matter what, I could not sim passed a certain day, buuuuuut, the developers are very helpful on the forum and I wrote a post, uploaded my save on there File Server, and in 3 days they had diagnosed the problem, and saved my save file and it was playable again. So HUGE shout-out  to the developer for being very supportive.To conclude:PROS:- Depth of game world- Scouting- Contracts- International Jobs- In depth statistics- Very helpful and responsive developersCONS:- Crashes (Although playable)TL:DR - Great game for anyone who loves sports sim games despite it's small flaws.10/10: Would buy again and support small developer.

												Franchise Hockey Manager 3 is a brilliant simulation of being a GM/Coach in the World of Ice Hockey.
